elements.title: Orders
elements.description: The following tests will test the functionality of Order entities in the database.

tests.title: Creating a new Order.
tests.description: When a user first logs on, or a previous order completes, a new order is created.
tests.expected_output: A new open order is created, with the correct date and time

prefix_elements.text: Below is the orders table before opening the tills software. Take note of the current latest order.

suffix_elements.text: The new order is correctly created.

tests.title: Deleting Current Order when shutting down.
tests.description: When the tills are shutdown, the current order should be deleted.
tests.expected_output: The current order on the tills should be removed from the database once the till is shutdown

prefix_elements.text: The current order on the till is Order #2 [OrderID: 741]

suffix_elements.text: After closing, Order #2 no longer exists.

tests.title: Don't allow the deletion of an order which has been partially paid for
tests.description: When attempting to shutdown, if an order has already been partially paid for, the order cannot be deleted, as this would cause the foregin key constraints to fail. As such, orders which have an associated transaction cannot be deleted.
tests.expected_output: Shutdown should be canceled, and the order should remain in the database.

prefix_elements.text: Below is Order #2, which has had £2 paid for already.

suffix_elements.text: After attempting to close the till software, I received the following pop-up:
After checking the database, the order is still present.

tests.title: Closing an order once fully paid.
tests.description: Once an order has been fully paid for, the order should close, and a new one should be created.
tests.expected_output: The current order should be marked as close once the final transaction has been made, and a new order should be created.

prefix_elements.text: Below is the same partially paid order:

suffix_elements.text: Once the remainder of the order is paid for, a new order is created and the previous order is closed.

tests.title: Assigning an Order Number
tests.description: When an order is created, it is assigned a user-friendly Order Number which allows both customers and staff to easily identify an order.
tests.expected_output: The new order should be 1 higher than the previous order. In this case, the previous number was 3, so the new order's number should be 4.

prefix_elements.text: Below is the current order, with an order number of 3. When this order completes and a new order is created, it should have an order number of 4.

suffix_elements.text: Once the previous order was completed, the new order was correctly assigned an order number of 4.

tests.title: Assigning an Order Number - Max Value
tests.description: The largest order number an order can have is 99. Once 99 is reached, order numbers should wrap around.
tests.expected_output: Once Order #99 Completes, the new order should have an order number of 1.

prefix_elements.text: Below is the current order, with a number of 99. Once this order completes, the new order should have a number of 1.

suffix_elements.text: The new order was correctly assigned an order number of 1.

tests.title: Assigning an Order Number - New Day
tests.description: Order Numbers rest back to 1 at the start of each day. As such, the first order of the day should have an order number of 1.
tests.expected_output: The new order will have an order number of 1.

prefix_elements.text: At the time of this test, the date is the 12/03/2024.
Below you can see that no orders have been made on this date.

suffix_elements.text: Once the tills have been open for the first time today, the newly created order is correctly assigned a number of 1.

elements.title: Order Basket
elements.description: The order basket displays what order items are currently in the basket, as well as a running total of the order's cost. The basket also allows for the deletion and modification of order items.

tests.title: Add Item
tests.description: When a menu button is clicked, the menu item is the appended to the end of the basket.
tests.expected_output: The clicked menu button should add it's respecitve menu item to the end of the order basket, as well as create a new associated OrderItem entry in the database. The stock of the item should also decrement by 1.

prefix_elements.text: In this test, I will click on the "Burger" menu button, which should add 1 burger item to the order basket.
The burger item has a Stock ID of 0, meaning a new Order Item should be created which references both StockID 0, as well as OrderID 748 (The current Order).
As seen below, there is no Order Item which corresponds to Order ID 748:

suffix_elements.text: When the "Burger" button is pressed, the respective Burger item is added to the basket and selected.
A new OrderItem entry is also created:
The stock for the Burger is also decremented by 1:
The subtotal is also correctly updated:

tests.title: Remove Item
tests.description: Cashiers should be able to remove items from the order basket.
tests.expected_output: When the "Delete" button is pressed while an order item is selected in the basket, it should be removed from the basket, the subtotal should update, the order item should be deleted from the database, and the stock should be updated to reflect this.

prefix_elements.text: Below is the same order as the previous test, with the same Burger item in the basket.

suffix_elements.text: The order item is correctly removed from the basket, the subtotal is set back to 0, and the delete (as well as the other modification buttons) are disabled, as no order item is selected.
The order item has also been deleted, as there are now no items corrisponding to OrderID 748
The stock has also been updated to reflect the deletion of the order item, brining it back up to the starting quantity of 50

tests.title: Creating A Meal
tests.description: Cashiers should be able to select items in the basket and make them into a meal when the "Combo" button is pressed.
tests.expected_output: When the "Combo" button is pressed, The selected item should become a meal, and a "Fries" and a "Coke" should be added as part of the meal. These items should be added as Order Items in the database, and their stock should decrease by 1. The subtotal should also update to reflect the new items.

prefix_elements.text: Below is an order containing a Cheese Burger item in the basket. When the combo button is pressed, a Cheese Burger Meal should be created, containing the Cheese Burger, as well as a Coke and Fries

suffix_elements.text: The meal was successfully created, and the subtotal was correctly updated to reflect this
These 2 new items can also be found in the database:

tests.title: De-Comboing a meal down to it's main item
tests.description: There are many times an employee may wish to de-combo a meal (E.g. A customer changes their mind). Therefore, it is important for cashiers to be able to convert a selected meal back to its core item by pressing the "Combo" button again.
tests.expected_output: When the "Combo" button is pressed, the Cheese Burger Meal should become just a Cheese Burger, and the Coke and Fries should be removed from the order. The Database and subtotal should both reflect this.

prefix_elements.text: Below is the Cheeseburger meal. Once the Combo button is pressed, it should return to just a Cheese Burger, and the subtotal should update.
These are the 3 meal items associated with this order:

suffix_elements.text: The meal correctly became just a Cheese Burger, and the subtotal was updated to reflect this.
The Coke and Fries items where also removed from the database

tests.title: Upsizing a Meal
tests.description: Bobby's Burgers offer both large and small variations of their meals. This test will be testing the upsizing functionality.
tests.expected_output: Expected Output: Once the Upsize button is pressed, the selected meal will become a "Large" meal, where the prefix "Large" will be added to all items (Except the main burger item), and the prices will be updated

elements.title: Payment
elements.description: A vital part of this system is the ability for customers to pay for their orders. Customers can pay via both Cash and Card, and this software should allow for flexibility. This software should make it easy for cashiers to allow customer to pay however they please.

tests.title: Payment Keypad - Max Value
tests.description: There should be a limit to how much you can type into the payment keypad. In this test, I will repeatidly press the 9 button on the keypad until there is some form of feedback
tests.expected_output: The value displayed on the keypad should stop growing in size at a reasonable point.

prefix_elements.text: Below is the Payment Keypad before any value has been inputed:

suffix_elements.text: The software crashed after repeatidly pressing the 9 button.
The reasoning for this appears to be caused by an integer overflow. If the value entered onto the keypad becomes too big, the interger will overflow, causing a crash
A simple fix would be to use a string to strore the entered value, instead of an integer:

elements.title: Database Management
elements.description: A crutial piece of this software is the ability for the Manager to be able to perform CRUD opperations on the database. These tests will focus on ensuring all CRUD opperations work as expected, and no data becomes corrupted or invalidated.

tests.title: Changing an Employee's Name
tests.description: While uncommon, there are situations where an employee may wish to change their name (E.g. after marriage). In such cases, Employees should be allowed to change their names on the database system.
tests.expected_output: After changing an employee's name, their new name should appear at the bottom of the till software when logged in.

prefix_elements.text: For this test, we will be changing "Ian Fern"'s name to "Ian Smith".

suffix_elements.text: After changing Ian's name, I was unable to loggin with their pin. At first I assumed I had forgotten their pin, but after testing again with a new pin, the same issue occured
I believe this is due to the Pin Hasing Algorithm creating the Salt from the Employee's name:

Once an employee's name has been updated, passing the correct pin through the hasing algorithm will result in a different hash than the one stored in the database, because the input salt was different.

Possible solutions include storing the salt in the database along with the employee, updating the employee's pin hash if their name changes, or change how the salt is generated. A simple solution would be to use the employee's EmployeeID as the salt, as this will never change.

tests.title: Sorting Data By Column
tests.description: Like most software that displays some form of spreadsheet, users can sort rows by values in a specific column.
tests.expected_output: When clicking on a column header, the rows should be sorted by the values in the respective column

prefix_elements.text: For this test, I will be sorting the Stock by Quantity. Currently, it is sorted by StockID:

suffix_elements.text: While the rows were correctly sorted, there is now a discrepancy between the selected row, and the values displayed in the Update Fields:
This is almost certainly due to "Data" Field not also being sorted by the Data Grid when the rows are resorted:
This seems to be a flaw with the WPF DataGrid. A possible solution would be to sort the list manualy when the data grid is sorted.
After taking a look at the documentation for the DataGrid, I found the "OnSorting" event that fires when a grid is resorted:
According to the documentation, a data grid simply calls the default sorting method on the column. When this event fires, our custom grid could also call the default sorting method on the column.
